children.subject: I'm a CS + Applied math Major. I'm used to taking 3 difficult technicals every semester, but only one theory/pset class every semester. I'm really excited about all three of these classes!
I've taken pretty much all the required lower divs for CS and Math (aside from EE16B) and I've taken Data 100

Could you provide more context about your background? Classes youve taken, past semesters, how much you like math, etc. 

That will help me/others help you!

Math 110 is taught with Frenkel this semester, and he historically doesn't assign required hw.

However, you're right I do want to focus on the fundamentals for these classes, instead of rushing through the material.

I'll definitely think about it. Thanks for your advice!

I've taken Math110 and Stat140 so I can give my thoughts on those and add in what my friends have told me about 170. 

That's just a heavy pset load which could be difficult if you like to take a break when you're stuck on math to bang your head against some code instead (or that might be just me). 

Time commitment is an issue with this scedule. 

170 from what I hear is a large time suck with difficult psets. 

140 psets took me a long time - about 10-15 hrs/week also doing the strongly recommend practice problems. But I also went into 140 with a lot less math background than what you seem to have so the psets might not take you as long!

The semester I took Math110 (with Sug Woo Shin) we didn't actually turn in our homework - so I attempted all the posted problems per week, but I didn't stress about going to office hours to solve every single last problem, which saved me a ton of time (I of course made sure I understood the solutions once they came out). 

With your math/heavy load background, and if Math110 doesn't require you to turn in homework, then this schedule is laborious but doable. 

If its a different professor for 110, then it may be a different story. You can always try out all three courses and drop one, but my semester of 110 had a little easier first 3 weeks (mostly 54 review) as a heads up. 

The only thing to keep in mind when you pursue this is that each of these courses is *the* fundamental course for the field (imo) - make sure you can actually learn the fundamentals instead of frantically trying to complete the homeworks each week!

I took 110 and 140 with heavy loads and sometimes wish I could go back to learn it all deeper.
